2017|language=en-AU|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170623125415/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-06-23/steve-irwin-honoured-with-star-hollywood-walk-of-fame-in-2018/8646412|archivedate=23 June 2017|df=dmy-all}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-4631070/Steve-Irwin-receives-star-Hollywood-Walk-Fame.html|title=Steve Irwin receives star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame|work=Mail Online|access-date=23 June 2017|df=dmy-all}} The star was unveiled 26 April 2018.{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/5256956/steve-irwin-hollywood-walk-of-fame-star/|title=Steve Irwin Remembered With Star on Hollywood Walk of Fame|website=Time|language=en|access-date=2018-04-27|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180427035336/http://time.com/5256956/steve-irwin-hollywood-walk-of-fame-star/|archivedate=27 April 2018|df=dmy-all}} == Environmentalism == {{See also|Wildlife Warriors}} Irwin was a passionate conservationist and believed in promoting environmentalism by sharing his excitement about the natural world rather than preaching to people. He was concerned with conservation of [[Endangered species|endangered animals]] and [[Deforestation|land clearing]] leading to loss of habitat. He considered conservation to be the most important part of his work: "I consider myself a wildlife warrior. My mission is to save the world's endangered species." Irwin bought "large tracts of land" in Australia, Vanuatu, [[Fiji]] and the United States, which he described as "like [[national park]]s" and stressed the importance of people realising that they could each make a difference.{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/tv/enoughrope/transcripts/s960998.htm |title=Enough Rope with Andrew Denton – episode 30: Steve Irwin |accessdate=4 September 2006 |author=Denton, Andrew |authorlink=Andrew Denton |author2=Irwin, Steve |date=6 October 2003 |publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060710050845/http://www.abc.net.au/tv/enoughrope/transcripts/s960998.htm |archivedate=10 July 2006 |df=dmy-all }} Irwin founded the Steve Irwin Conservation Foundation, which became an independent charity and was later renamed "Wildlife Warriors Worldwide".[http://www.australiazoo.com.au/conservation/wildlife-warriors/ "Wildlife Warriors Worldwide"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110223000702/http://www.australiazoo.com.au/conservation/wildlife-warriors/ |date=23 February 2011 }}, ''Australia Zoo''. Retrieved 5 February 2011. He also helped found International Crocodile Rescue,[http://www.internationalcrocodilerescue.com.au/about_rescue_unit/index.html "ICR History"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110128141436/http://www.internationalcrocodilerescue.com.au/about_rescue_unit/index.html |date=28 January 2011 }}, ''International Crocodile Rescue''. Retrieved 5 February 2011. the Lyn Irwin Memorial Fund (named in memory of his mother, who died in an automobile crash in 2000),[http://www.australiazoo.com.au/conservation/lyn-irwin-memorial-fund/ "Lyn Irwin Memorial Fund"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110223030659/http://www.australiazoo.com.au/conservation/lyn-irwin-memorial-fund/ |date=23 February 2011 }}, ''Australia Zoo''. Retrieved 5 February 2011. and the Iron Bark Station Wildlife Rehabilitation Facility.[http://www.australiazoo.com.au/conservation/programs/habitat.php#Iron%20Bark%20Station "Iron Bark Station"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110312044553/http://www.australiazoo.com.au/conservation/programs/habitat.php |date=12 March 2011 }}, ''Australia Zoo''. Retrieved 5 February 2011. Irwin urged people to take part in considerate tourism and not support illegal [[poaching]] through the purchase of items such as turtle shells or [[shark-fin soup]].{{cite web |url = http://www.thefirstpost.co.uk/index.php?menuID=2&subID=883&p=3 |work = The First Post |title = Death of the crocodile hunter |date = 4 September 2006 |accessdate = 10 September 2006 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061012235957/http://www.thefirstpost.co.uk/index.php?menuID=2&subID=883&p=3 |archivedate = 12 October 2006 |df = dmy-all }} [[David Attenborough|Sir David Attenborough]] was an inspiration to Irwin, according to his widow. When presenting a [[Lifetime Achievement Award]] to Attenborough after Irwin's death at the British [[National Television Awards]] on 31 October 2006, Terri Irwin said, "If there's one person who directly inspired my husband it's the person being honoured tonight.... [Steve's] real, true love was conservation – and the influence of tonight's recipient in preserving the natural world has been immense."{{cite news | title = Wildlife legend honoured | work=ITN News | publisher=ITN | date = 1 November 2006 | url = http://www.itn.co.uk/news/entertainment_6bf41e7a55ac3b005e7946fe9fb592da.html | accessdate =1 November 2006 }} {{Dead link|date=April 2012|bot=H3llBot}} Attenborough reciprocated by praising Irwin for introducing many to the natural world, saying, "He taught them how wonderful and exciting it was, he was a born communicator." Irwin, after his death, was described by Mark Townend, CEO of [[RSPCA Australia|RSPCA]] Queensland, as a "modern-day [[Noah]]."{{cite news | url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/irwins-death-was-filmed/story-e6frevq9-1111112180323 | title=Irwin's death was filmed | first1=Luke | last1=McIlveen | author2=AAP | newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Daily Telegraph]] | location=Sydney | date=4 September 2006 | accessdate=16 January 2011 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120930133530/http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/irwins-death-was-filmed/story-e6frevq9-1111112180323 | archivedate=30 September 2012 | df=dmy-all }} British naturalist [[David Bellamy]] lauded his skills as a [[natural history|natural historian]] and media performer.{{cite news | url = http://today.reuters.com/News/CrisesArticle.aspx?storyId=SP68982 | title = Australia stunned by death of "modern-day Noah" | accessdate =4 September 2006 | last = Tait | first = Paul | date = 4 September 2006 |agency=Reuters |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080207070239/http://today.reuters.com/News/CrisesArticle.aspx?storyId=SP68982 |archivedate = 7 February 2008}} Canadian environmentalist [[David Suzuki]] paid tribute to Irwin, noting that "[h]umanity will not protect that which we fear or do not understand. Steve Irwin helped us understand those things that many people thought were a nuisance at best, a horror at worst. That made him a great educator and conservationist."{{cite web | url=http://www.davidsuzuki.org/blogs/science-matters/2006/11/crocodile-hunter-more-than-just-a-showman/ | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100503180510/http://www.davidsuzuki.org/blogs/science-matters/2006/11/crocodile-hunter-more-than-just-a-showman/ | dead-url=yes | archive-date=3 May 2010 | title=Crocodile Hunter more than just a showman | date=15 November 2006 | first1=David | last1=Suzuki | first2=Faisal | last2=Moola | authorlink=David Suzuki | publisher=[[David Suzuki Foundation]] | accessdate=16 January 2011 }} After his death, the vessel {{MV|Robert Hunter}} owned by the environmental action group [[Sea Shepherd Conservation Society]] was renamed {{MY|Steve Irwin}}.{{cite web|url=http://www.seashepherd.org/news/media_071205_1.html |title=Sea Shepherd Renames Its Whale Defending Ship the Steve Irwin |publisher=Sea Shepherd |date=5 December 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080105103720/http://www.seashepherd.org/news/media_071205_1.html |archivedate=5 January 2008 |df= }} Shortly before his death, Irwin had been investigating joining Sea Shepherd's 2007–2008 voyage to Antarctica to disrupt Japanese whaling activity. Following his death, the organisation suggested renaming their vessel, and this idea was endorsed by Terri Irwin.{{cite news | url=http://www.news.com.au/perthnow/story/0,21598,22874137-948,00.html | title=Sea Shepherd honours Steve Irwin | newspaper=Perth Now | date=4 December 2007 | first=Narelle | last=Towie | accessdate=18 January 2011 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120525132340/www.news.com.au/perthnow/story/0,21598,22874137-948,00.html | archivedate=25 May 2012 | df=dmy-all }} Regarding the ship and its new name, Terri said, "If Steve were alive, he'd be aboard with them!"{{cite news | url=http://www.ens-newswire.com/ens/dec2008/2008-12-26-02.html | title=Sea Shepherd Activists Cover Whaler with Stinky, Slimy Goo | publisher=Environment News Service | date=26 December 2008 | accessdate=18 January 2011 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110622014655/http://www.ens-newswire.com/ens/dec2008/2008-12-26-02.html | archivedate=22 June 2011 | df=dmy-all }} == Sporting activities == Irwin loved [[mixed martial arts]] competitions and trained with Greg Jackson in the fighting/grappling system of [[Gaidojutsu]].[http://www.jacksons.tv/mma/index.php Jackson's Gaidojutsu Self Defense] www.jacksons.tv. Retrieved 7 September 2006. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923141512/http://www.jacksons.tv/mma/index.php |date=23 September 2015 }} Like many Australians, he was an avid cricket fan. This was seen during his visit to [[Sri Lanka]] where he played cricket with some local children and said "I love cricket" and "It's a shame we have to go catch some snakes now". This was seen during the ''Crocodile Hunter'' episode "Island of the Snakes".{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UKdXrSjVdOM&feature=related |title=Island of Snakes part 6 |date=26 February 2008 |accessdate=26 February 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131216142737/http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UKdXrSjVdOM&feature=related |archivedate=16 December 2013 |df=dmy }} Having grown up in Essendon, Irwin was a fan of the [[Essendon Football Club|Essendon Bombers]], an [[Australian rules football]] club in the [[Australian Football League]].[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,60-2342450,00.html "Steve Irwin"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080725004047/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,60-2342450,00.html |date=25 July 2008 }} The Times Online 5 September 2006. Retrieved 6 September 2006 Irwin took part in an Australian Rules football promotion in Los Angeles as part of "Australia Week" in early 2006.[http://www.australia-week.com/page/AFLMatchSteveIrwinShow AFL Match, Steve Irwin Show]. Retrieved 5 September 2006 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070205045829/http://www.australia-week.com/page/AFLMatchSteveIrwinShow |date=5 February 2007 }} After his death, a picture of Irwin wearing a Bombers Guernsey was shown by [[ESPN.com]] in their [[Bottom 10]] ranking of the worst [[Football Bowl Subdivision|Division I FBS]] [[college football]] teams after Week 1 of the season in tribute to him.{{cite web | url = http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/news/story?id=2573548 | title = The Bottom 10: Have a look at this beauty | first = David | last = Duffey | publisher = ESPN | date = 6 September 2006 | accessdate = 11 September 2006 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061103210229/http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/news/story?id=2573548 | archivedate = 3 November 2006 | df = dmy-all }} Having lived in Queensland most of his life, Irwin was also a fan of [[rugby league]]. As a teenager, he played for the Caloundra Sharks as a second-rower,[http://www.news.com.au/couriermail/story/0,23739,20383719-3102,00.html Our mate Steve] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071113171046/http://www.news.com.au/couriermail/story/0,23739,20383719-3102,00.html |date=13 November 2007 }}. Retrieved 12 September 2006 and as an adult he was known to be a passionate [[Brisbane Broncos]] fan and was involved with the club on several occasions. On one occasion after turning up to training he asked if he could tackle the largest player, [[Shane Webcke]]. Despite being thrown to the ground and looking like he'd been crushed he was jovial about the experience. Irwin laughingly shared the experience with the [[Queensland state rugby league team|Queensland]] [[Rugby League State of Origin|State of Origin]] squad before the 2006 series.[http://www.news.com.au/story/0,10117,20350166-2,00.html Tributes flow for 'true original']. Retrieved 12 September 2006 {{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Irwin also supported [[rugby union]], being a fan of the national team, the [[Australia national rugby union team|Wallabies]]. He once wore a Wallaby jersey during a demonstration at the zoo. A behind-the-scenes episode of ''The Crocodile Hunter'' showed Irwin and the crew finding a petrol station in a remote part of [[Namibia]] to watch the Wallabies defeat [[France national rugby union team|France]] in the [[1999 Rugby World Cup]] Final. Irwin was also a talented surfer.{{cite web | url = http://www.sunshinecoastdaily.com.au/localnews/storydisplay.cfm?storyid=3699961&thesection=localnews&thesubsection=&thesecondsubsection | title = Surfers invited to pay tribute | date = 6 September 2006 | accessdate =7 November 2006 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} == Controversies == [[File:MV Steve Irwin Melbourne.jpg|thumb|{{MY|Steve Irwin}} approaching Melbourne in February 2008]] A controversial incident occurred during a public show on 2 January 2004, when Irwin carried his one-month-old son, [[Robert Irwin (television personality)|Robert]], in his arm while hand-feeding a chicken carcass to Murray, a {{convert|3.8|m|ftin|adj=on}} saltwater crocodile. The infant was close to the crocodile, and comparisons were made in the press to [[Michael Jackson]]'s dangling his son outside a German hotel window.{{cite news | title = It's like a part of Australia has died | author=Patrick Barkham | url = https://www.theguardian.com/australia/story/0,,1865085,00.html | work=The Guardian | date = 5 September 2006 | accessdate =5 September 2006 | location=London}} In addition, some child welfare groups, [[animal rights]] groups, and some of Irwin's television viewers criticised his actions as irresponsible and tantamount to [[child abuse]].{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/3364733.stm |title=Inquiry into croc baby stunt |accessdate=4 September 2006 |date=3 January 2004 |publisher=BBC News |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070115075946/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/3364733.stm |archivedate=15 January 2007 |df=dmy-all }} Irwin apologised on the US NBC show ''[[Today (U.S. TV program)|Today]]''.{{cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/dailytelegraph/story/0,22049,20349993-5001021,00.html |title=Irwin's Death was Filmed |first=Luke |last=McIlveen |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=UK |date=4 September 2006 |accessdate=9 February 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060920134854/http://www.news.com.au/dailytelegraph/story/0%2C22049%2C20349993-5001021%2C00.html |archivedate=20 September 2006 |df= }} Both he and his wife publicly stated that Irwin was in complete control of the situation, as he had dealt with crocodiles since he was a small child, and based on his lifetime of experience neither he nor his son was in any danger. He also showed footage of the event shot from a different angle, demonstrating that they were much farther from the crocodile than they had appeared in the publicised clip.{{cite news | url = http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2004/01/15/1073877890197.html | title = TV's mixed messages | first = Jim | last = Schembri | work = The Age | location = Australia | date = 15 January 2004 | accessdate = 31 January 2007 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071113094207/http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2004/01/15/1073877890197.html | archivedate = 13 November 2007 | df = dmy-all }} Terri Irwin said their child was in no more danger than one being taught to swim. No charges were filed; according to one journalist, Irwin told officials he would not repeat the action.{{cite news | url = http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2004/01/04/1073151212433.html | title = Croc hunter ducks for cover | first = Claire | last = O'Rourke | work = The Sydney Morning Herald | date = 5 January 2004 | accessdate = 4 September 2006 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060512191014/http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2004/01/04/1073151212433.html | archivedate = 12 May 2006 | df = dmy-all }} The incident prompted the Queensland government to change its crocodile-handling laws, banning children and untrained adults from entering crocodile enclosures.{{cite news |title = Steve Irwin baby concerns prompt law change |url = http://www.smh.com.au/news/National/Steve-Irwin-baby-concerns-prompt-law-change/2005/02/23/1109046983142.html |work = The Sydney Morning Herald |date = 24 February 2005 |accessdate = 4 September 2006 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061005100924/http://www.smh.com.au/news/National/Steve-Irwin-baby-concerns-prompt-law-change/2005/02/23/1109046983142.html |archivedate = 5 October 2006 |df = dmy-all }} In June 2004, allegations were made that he disturbed wildlife (namely whales, seals and penguins) while filming a documentary, ''Ice Breaker'', in [[Antarctica]]. The matter was subsequently closed without charges being laid.{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/3896685.stm | title = Irwin cleared after Penguin Probe | publisher = BBC News | date = 15 June 2004 | accessdate = 4 September 2006 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060306075536/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/3896685.stm | archivedate = 6 March 2006 | df = dmy-all }} After questions arose in 2003 about Irwin being paid $175,000 worth of taxpayers' money to appear in a television advertisement and his possible political ties, Irwin told the [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] (ABC) that he was a conservationist and did not choose sides in politics. His comments describing Australian Prime Minister [[John Howard]] as the "greatest leader in the world" earned him scorn in the media.{{cite news | first =Miranda | last =Devine | title =Crikey! Praise for PM puts you in a snake pit | url =http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2003/11/08/1068243301741.html | work =The Sun-Herald | date =9 November 2003 | accessdate =5 September 2006 | deadurl =no | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20060512190824/http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2003/11/08/1068243301741.html | archivedate =12 May 2006 | df =dmy-all }} Irwin was criticised for having an unsophisticated view of [[conservation in Australia]] that seemed more linked to tourism than to the problems Australia faces as a [[Australia (continent)|continent]]. In response to questions of Australia's problems with [[overgrazing]], [[Salinity in Australia|salinity]], and [[erosion]], Irwin responded, "Cows have been on our land for so long that Australia has evolved to handle those big animals." ''The Sydney Morning Herald'' concluded with the opinion that his message was confusing and amounted to "eating roos and crocs is bad for tourism, and therefore more cruel than eating other animals".{{cite news|first=Frank|last=Robson|url=http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2006/09/04/1157222053963.html?page=fullpage|title=Crikey, it's raw Stevo!|work=Good Weekend|date=4 September 2006|accessdate=5 September 2006|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071015075645/http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2006/09/04/1157222053963.html?page=fullpage|archivedate=15 October 2007|df=dmy-all}} == Death == On 4 September 2006, Irwin was on location at [[Batt Reef]], near [[Port Douglas, Queensland]], taking part in the production of the documentary series ''[[Ocean's Deadliest]]''. During a lull in filming caused by inclement weather, Irwin decided to [[snorkeling|snorkel]] in shallow waters while being filmed in an effort to provide footage for [[Bindi the Jungle Girl|his daughter's television programme]]. While swimming in chest-deep water, Irwin approached a [[short-tail stingray]] with an approximate span of two metres (6.5 ft) from the rear, in order to film it swimming away. According to the incident's only witness, “All of a sudden [the stingray] propped on its front and started stabbing wildly with its tail. Hundreds of strikes in a few seconds”. Irwin initially believed he only had a punctured lung. However, the [[Stingray injury|stingray's barb]] pierced his heart, causing him to [[Exsanguination|bleed to death]].{{cite news|last=Selby|first=Jenn|title=Steve Irwin's final words: Cameraman present at death opens up about deadly stingray attack for the first time|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/news/steve-irwins-final-words-cameraman-present-at-death-opens-up-about-deadly-stingray-attack-for-the-first-time-9181077.html|accessdate=10 March 2014|newspaper=The Independent|date=10 March 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140310154552/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/news/steve-irwins-final-words-cameraman-present-at-death-opens-up-about-deadly-stingray-attack-for-the-first-time-9181077.html|archivedate=10 March 2014|df=dmy-all}}Bond, Nick [http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/entertainment/television/cameraman-justin-lyons-reveals-steve-irwins-final-words-im-dying/story-fni0cc2b-1226850585833 "Cameraman Justin Lyons reveals Steve Irwin's final words: 'I'm dying'"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140313000930/http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/entertainment/television/cameraman-justin-lyons-reveals-steve-irwins-final-words-im-dying/story-fni0cc2b-1226850585833 |date=13 March 2014 }} ''The Advertiser'', South Australia (10 March 2014). Retrieved 10 March 2014. The stingray's behaviour appeared to have been a defensive response to being boxed in. Crew members aboard Irwin's boat administered [[CPR]] and rushed him to the nearby [[Low Isles]] where medical staff pronounced him dead.{{cite news|title=Croc Hunter Irwin killed by stingray|work=The Age|location=Australia|date=4 September 2006|url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/National/Croc-Hunter-Steve-Irwin-died-instantly/2006/09/04/1157222051588.html|accessdate=4 September 2006|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061022053436/http://www.theage.com.au/news/National/Croc-Hunter-Steve-Irwin-died-instantly/2006/09/04/1157222051588.html|archivedate=22 October 2006|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|title=Farewell to a larrikin adventurer, killed in his prime|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/farewell-to-a-larrikin-adventurer-killed-in-his-prime/2006/09/04/1157222072696.html?page=fullpage|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=5 September 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121107165657/http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/farewell-to-a-larrikin-adventurer-killed-in-his-prime/2006/09/04/1157222072696.html?page=fullpage|archivedate=7 November 2012|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news | title = Death of a Crocodile Hunter | url = http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1531446,00.html | author = Rory Callinan | work = Time | date = 4 http://www.cnn.com/2006/WORLD/asiapcf/09/04/australia.irwin.stingray.reut/index.html |agency=Reuters |publisher=CNN | date = 4 September 2006 | accessdate =4 September 2006 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060921002229/http://www.cnn.com/2006/WORLD/asiapcf/09/04/australia.irwin.stingray.reut/index.html |archivedate = 21 September 2006}} Footage of the incident was viewed by Queensland state police as part of their mandatory investigations. All copies of the footage were then destroyed at the behest of Irwin's family.{{cite news|first1=Ian |last1=Gerard |last2=Koch |first2=Tony |title=Steve Irwin's freak death filmed |url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,20867,20355112-601,00.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060911010650/http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0%2C20867%2C20355112-601%2C00.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=11 September 2006 |work=The Australian |date=4 September 2006 |accessdate=4 September 2006 |df= }}{{cite news | title = Irwin's dad: 'I lost my best mate' |publisher=CNN | date = 6 September 2006 | url = http://www.cnn.com/2006/SHOWBIZ/TV/09/06/death.irwin/index.html | accessdate =7 September 2006 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060923022509/http://www.cnn.com/2006/SHOWBIZ/TV/09/06/death.irwin/index.html |archivedate = 23 September 2006}}{{cite news | title = Widow: 'Croc Hunter' thought he'd die young |publisher=CNN | date=27 September 2006 | url = http://www.cnn.com/2006/SHOWBIZ/09/26/irwin.terri.ap/index.html | accessdate =30 September 2006 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060928131557/http://www.cnn.com/2006/SHOWBIZ/09/26/irwin.terri.ap/index.html |archivedate = 28 September 2006}}{{cite news | title = Steve Irwin death film given to wife | publisher=Yahoo! News | date = 3 January 2007 | url = http://ca.news.yahoo.com/s/reuters/entertainment_australia_irwin_col | accessdate =4 January 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070115031855/http://ca.news.yahoo.com/s/reuters/entertainment_australia_irwin_col |archivedate = 15 January 2007}}{{cite news|url=http://www.upi.com/NewsTrack/view.php?StoryID=20070111-024500-6651r| title=Video of 'Croc Hunter's' death destroyed| agency=United Press International|date=11 January 2007|accessdate=12 January 2007|archiveurl=http://www.upi.com/Entertainment_News/2007/01/11/Video-of-Croc-Hunters-death-destroyed/UPI-66511168548547|archivedate=11 January 2007}} Production was completed on ''Ocean's Deadliest'', which was broadcast in the US on the [[Discovery Channel]] on 21 January 2007. The documentary was completed with footage shot in the weeks following the accident, but without including any mention of Irwin's accidental death.{{cite news | url=http://www.news.com.au/story/0,23599,20989738-2,00.html | title=Crocodile Hunter's final stunt with sea snake | work=The Daily Telegraph | location=UK | date=30 December 2006 | accessdate=15 April 2007 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070503175435/http://www.news.com.au/story/0,23599,20989738-2,00.html | archivedate=3 May 2007 | df=dmy-all }}{{cite news | url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/20070106/steve-irwin-show.htm | title=Crocodile Hunter's Last Show Completed | work=International Business Times | date=6 January 2007 | accessdate=6 January 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070107234634/http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/20070106/steve-irwin-show.htm |archivedate = 7 January 2007}} === Reactions === News of Irwin's death prompted reactions around the world. Then-Prime Minister [[John Howard]] expressed "shock and distress" at the death, saying that "Australia has lost a wonderful and colourful son."{{cite news | title = 'Crocodile Hunter' killed in sea incident | url = http://www.rte.ie/news/2006/0904/irwins.html | publisher = [[RTÉ News]] | date = 4 September 2006 | accessdate = 16 January 2011 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121102181058/http://www.rte.ie/news/2006/0904/irwins.html | archivedate = 2 November 2012 | df = dmy-all }} Queensland's then-[[Premiers of Queensland|Premier]] [[Peter Beattie]] remarked that Irwin would "be remembered as not just a great Queenslander, but a great Australian".{{cite news | url = http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/irwin-death-footage-terrible/2006/09/05/1157222098946.html?page=fullpage | title = Irwin didn't intimidate stingray | work = The Sydney Morning Herald | date = 5 September 2006 | accessdate = 15 January 2011 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121107130414/http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/irwin-death-footage-terrible/2006/09/05/1157222098946.html?page=fullpage | archivedate = 7 November 2012 | df = dmy-all }} The Australian [[Australian Parliament|federal parliament]] opened on 5 September 2006 with condolence speeches by both Howard and the [[Opposition (Australia)|Leader of the Opposition]], [[Kim Beazley]]. Flags at the Sydney Harbour Bridge were lowered to [[half mast]] in honour of Irwin.[http://www.news.com.au/harbour-bridge-flags-lowered-for-icons/story-e6frfkp9-1111112233997 "Harbour Bridge flags lowered for icons"], [[News Corporation]] (news.com.au), 19 September 2006. In the days following Irwin's death, reactions dominated Australian online news sources,{{cite web | url = http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2006/09/05/1157222114384.html?page=fullpage | title = Croc Hunter news consumes the web | work = The Age | location = Australia | date = 5 September 2006 | accessdate = 8 September 2006 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071113094212/http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2006/09/05/1157222114384.html?page=fullpage | archivedate = 13 November 2007 | df = dmy-all }} talk-back radio programmes,{{cite news | first = Richard | last = Fidler | title = Tributes flow for Steve Irwin | url = http://www.abc.net.au/brisbane/stories/s1732538.htm | publisher=612 ABC radio | date = 4 September 2006 | accessdate =4 September 2006 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071011190156/http://abc.net.au/brisbane/stories/s1732538.htm |archivedate = 11 October 2007}} and television networks.''[[Seven Network]]'' [https://archive.is/20071020013025/http://au.news.yahoo.com/060905/23/10erm.html "Yahoo7 TV Tribute to Steve Irwin"] In the [[United States]], where Irwin had appeared in over 200 Discovery Network television programmes, special tributes appeared on the Animal Planet channel, as well as on [[CNN]] and major TV talk shows.''[[Reuters]]'' [http://today.reuters.com/news/articleinvesting.aspx?view=CN&storyID=2006-09-04T213925Z_01_N04279992_RTRIDST_0_AUSTRALIA-IRWIN-MEDIA.XML&rpc=66&type=qcna "Discovery network mourns Irwin, plans tribute"]{{dead link|date=April 2018|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}''[[Sydney Morning Herald]]'' [http://www.smh.com.au/news/world/aussie-superman-brings-tears-to-us-chat-shows/2006/09/06/1157222169182.html "Aussie 'Superman' brings tears to US chat shows"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070302194713/http://www.smh.com.au/news/world/aussie-superman-brings-tears-to-us-chat-shows/2006/09/06/1157222169182.html |date=2 March 2007 }} Thousands of Irwin's fans visited Australia Zoo after his death, paying their respects and bringing flowers, candles, stuffed animals and messages of support.{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/newsitems/200609/s1733664.htm |title=Beattie flags Steve Irwin award, national park |publisher=ABC |date=5 September 2006 |accessdate=7 September 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011190221/http://abc.net.au/news/newsitems/200609/s1733664.htm |archivedate=11 October 2007 }}{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/5340906.stm | title = 'Crocoseum' tribute set for Irwin | publisher = BBC | date = 13 September 2006 | accessdate = 13 September 2006 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120616115521/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/5340906.stm | archivedate = 16 June 2012 | df = dmy-all }} Criticism of Irwin's career following his death came from [[Dan Mathews]], vice-president of the animal rights group [[People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals]]. Comparing Irwin to a "cheap reality TV star", Mathews accused him of "antagonising frightened wild animals ... a very dangerous message to send to children", contrasted his methods with the behaviour of "a responsible conservationist like [[Jacques-Yves Cousteau|Jacques Cousteau]]", and said it was "no shock at all that Steve Irwin should die provoking a dangerous animal."{{cite news | last = AAP | title = Irwin's antics 'a danger to children' | url = http://www.theage.com.au/news/national/irwins-antics-a-danger-to-children/2006/09/13/1157826993532.html | work = The Age | location = Australia | date = 13 September 2006 | accessdate = 13 September 2006 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070929144342/http://www.theage.com.au/news/national/irwins-antics-a-danger-to-children/2006/09/13/1157826993532.html | archivedate = 29 September 2007 | df = dmy-all }}{{cite news | author=Walls, Jeannette | url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/14626178/ | title=PETA sheds no crocodile tears for Steve Irwin | publisher=MSNBC | accessdate=14 September 2006 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060914075305/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/14626178/ | archivedate=14 September 2006 | df=dmy-all }} The son of Jacques Cousteau, [[Jean-Michel Cousteau]]—also a producer of wildlife documentaries—took issue with Irwin's "very, very spectacular, dramatic way of presenting things" and suggested instead that "You don't touch nature, you just look at it."{{cite news | url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/world/irwin-interfered-with-nature-says-cousteau/2006/09/20/1158431752163.html | title=Irwin interfered with nature, says Cousteau | work=The Sydney Morning Herald | date=20 September 2006 | accessdate=20 September 2006 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071015215248/http://www.smh.com.au/news/world/irwin-interfered-with-nature-says-cousteau/2006/09/20/1158431752163.html | archivedate=15 October 2007 | df=dmy-all }} Jacques Cousteau's grandson and Jean-Michel's nephew, [[Philippe Cousteau Jr.]], on the other hand, called Irwin "a remarkable individual"; describing the ''Ocean's Deadliest'' project (on which he worked along with Irwin), Philippe said, "I think why Steve was so excited about it that we were looking at these animals that people think of as, you know, dangerous and deadly monsters, and they're not. They all have an important place in the environment and in the world. And that was what his whole message was about."{{cite news | url=http://www.cnn.com/2006/SHOWBIZ/TV/09/06/cnna.cousteau/index.html | title=Cousteau: Irwin a 'remarkable individual' | publisher=CNN | date=6 September 2006 | accessdate=22 October 2006 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060923022032/http://www.cnn.com/2006/SHOWBIZ/TV/09/06/cnna.cousteau/index.html | archivedate=23 September 2006 | df=dmy-all }} In the weeks following Irwin's death, at least ten stingrays were found dead and mutilated on the beaches of Queensland, with their tails cut off, prompting speculation as to whether they might have been killed by fans of Irwin as an act of revenge, although, according to the chairman of the Queensland fishing information service, anglers regularly cut the tails off of accidentally caught stingrays to avoid being stung.{{cite news| url = http://www.couriermail.com.au/news/queensland/stingray-deaths-under-investigation/story-e6freoof-1111112201760| title = Stingray deaths under investigation| deadurl = no| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120920015328/http://www.couriermail.com.au/news/queensland/stingray-deaths-under-investigation/story-e6freoof-1111112201760| archivedate = 20 September 2012| df = dmy-all}} Michael Hornby, a friend of Irwin and executive director of his Wildlife Warrior fund, condemned any revenge killings, saying that "We just want to make it very clear that we will not accept and not stand for anyone who's taken a form of retribution. That's the last thing Steve would want."{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/5338118.stm | title = Irwin fans 'in revenge attacks' | publisher = BBC | date = 12 September 2006 | accessdate = 12 September 2006 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061021015359/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/5338118.stm | archivedate = 21 October 2006 | df = dmy-all }} === Funeral and memorial services === Family and friends of Irwin held a private funeral service in [[Caloundra]] on 9 September 2006.{{cite news | first = Lou | last = Robson | title = Family says private farewell | url = http://www.news.com.au/sundaymail/story/0,23739,20383870-3102,00.html | publisher=The Sunday Mail | date = 10 September 2006 | accessdate =10 September 2006 }} Irwin was buried in a private ceremony at [[Australia Zoo]] later that same day; the grave site is inaccessible to the zoo's visitors. Prime Minister Howard and Queensland Premier Beattie had offered to hold a [[state funeral]], but Irwin's family decided this would not be appropriate and—in the words of his father—he would have preferred to be remembered as an "ordinary [[bloke]]".{{cite news | url = http://www.theage.com.au/news/national/father-rejects-state-funeral-for-ordinary-bloke-son/2006/09/06/1157222201277.html | title = Father rejects state funeral for 'ordinary bloke' son | work = The Age | location = Australia | date = 7 September 2006 | accessdate = 7 September 2006 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060907153325/http://www.theage.com.au/news/national/father-rejects-state-funeral-for-ordinary-bloke-son/2006/09/06/1157222201277.html | archivedate = 7 September 2006 | df = dmy-all }} [[File:Australia zoo-Raffi Kojian-CIMG6415.JPG|thumb|The "Crocoseum" at [[Australia Zoo]], where Steve Irwin's memorial service was held.]] On 20 September, a public memorial service, introduced by [[Russell Crowe]], was held in Australia Zoo's 5,500-seat Crocoseum; this service was broadcast live throughout Australia, the United States, the UK, Germany, and Asia, and it is estimated to have been seen by over 300 million viewers worldwide.{{cite news | url = http://www.ecanadanow.com/world/2006/09/19/300-million-people-to-watch-steve-irwin-memorial/ | title = 300 Million People To Watch Steve Irwin Memorial | publisher = ecanadanow.com | date = 19 September 2006 | accessdate = 13 September 2006 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061026205438/http://www.ecanadanow.com/world/2006/09/19/300-million-people-to-watch-steve-irwin-memorial/ | archivedate = 26 October 2006 | df = dmy-all }} The memorial included remarks by Prime Minister Howard; Irwin's father Bob and daughter Bindi; his associates [[Wes Mannion]] and [[John Stainton]]; and celebrities from Australia and around the world.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2006/SHOWBIZ/TV/09/19/crocodile.hunter.service/index.html| title= Thousands mourn 'Crocodile Hunter'|publisher=CNN|date=20 September 2006|accessdate=20 September 2006 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060920222510/http://www.cnn.com/2006/SHOWBIZ/TV/09/19/crocodile.hunter.service/index.html |archivedate = 20 September 2006}} [[Anthony Field]] of [[The Wiggles]] partly hosted the service, often sharing the screen with various animals, from koalas to elephants. Australian music star [[John Williamson (singer)|John Williamson]] sang "[[True Blue (John Williamson song)|True Blue]]", which was Irwin's favourite song. In a symbolic finish to the service, Irwin's truck was loaded up with gear and driven out of the arena for the last time as Williamson sang. As a final tribute, Australia Zoo staff spelled out Irwin's catchphrase "Crikey" in yellow flowers as Irwin's truck was driven from the Crocoseum for the last time to end the service. == Related events == On 1 January 2007, Glass House Mountains Road, the road that runs by the Australia Zoo, was officially renamed Steve Irwin Way.[http://www.news.com.au/couriermail/story/0,23739,21005087-3102,00.html Steve Irwin gets his Way] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071113171051/http://www.news.com.au/couriermail/story/0,23739,21005087-3102,00.html |date=13 November 2007 }}. Retrieved 2 January 2007 The Australian government announced in July 2007 that a 135,000-hectare (334,000-acre) national park was being created in northern Queensland and would be named the Steve Irwin Wildlife Reserve.[http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2007/07/22/1984870.htm "Govt to buy Cape York land for Irwin memorial reserve"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070808082946/http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2007/07/22/1984870.htm |date=8 August 2007 }}, ABC News, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, 22 July 2007.{{cite news | url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/arts/tv/story/2007/07/23/irwin-reserve.html | title=Australia to name wildlife reserve after Steve Irwin | publisher=[[CBC News]] | date=23 July 2007 | accessdate=28 December 2012}} An [[asteroid]] discovered in 2001 has been named [[57567 Crikey]], in honour of Irwin and his "signature phrase".{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uwGbkbhMVyAC&pg=PA154&lpg=PA154&dq=%2Bcrikey+%2B57567+%2Basteroid&source=bl&ots=iiPpiTb_R7&sig=1-4IsNmcw-bX3h2EE5MlDwXD9Ww&hl=en&ei=cScRTrn7EITWtQOd26mODg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&sqi=2&ved=0CC0Q6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=%2Bcrikey%20%2B57567%20%2Basteroid&f=false | title=Dictionary of Minor Planet Names: Addendum to Fifth Edition: 2006–2008 | page=154 | last=Schmadel | first=Lutz D. | isbn=978-3-642-01964-7 | publisher=Springer-Verlag | year=2009 | accessdate=4 July 2011 }}{{cite web | url=http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=57567 | title=57567 Crikey (2001 TS56) | publisher=[[NASA]] [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] | date=7 August 2007 | accessdate=28 December 2012}} == Filmography == {{ref improve|section|date=September 2017}} {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#b0c4de; text-align:center;" ! {{About-distinguish|The Millennium Project|United Nations Millennium Project}} {{Infobox organization |name = The Millennium Project |image = LogoTMP_240.png |image_border = |abbreviation = MP |type = [[Non-profit]] |status = Association |purpose = Global Futures Research |headquarters = Washington D.C. |region_served = Worldwide |leader_title = Executive directors |leader_name = [[Jerome C. Glenn]],December 19, 2013, USA Today, [https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2013/12/19/moogfest-announces-music-kraftwerk-nile-rodgers/4125501/ Moogfest announces music: Kraftwerk, Nile Rodgers], Retrieved July 9, 2015, "..Jerome C. Glenn: Co-founder & director of The Millennium Project...."
Theodore J. Gordon,
Elizabeth Florescu |website = {{URL|http://millennium-project.org}} }} '''The Millennium Project''' is an independent non-profit [[think tank]] composed of futurists, Torie Bosch, Slate Magazine, October 31, 2011, [http://www.slate.com/blogs/future_tense/2011/10/31/futurists_and_futurologists_get_paid_by_major_companies_to_antic.html Is Being a Futurist a Real Job?], Retrieved July 9, 2015, "...Mackenzie quotes one futurist, the Millennium Project's Jerome C. Glenn, as saying,..." scholars, decision-makers, and business planners, which focuses on the future. It publishes its annual ''State of the Future'' report.{{cite news|author=Jonathan Owen |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/environment/nature/state-of-the-future-report-humans-are-doing-ok-but-nature-suffers-as-a-result--and-well-pay-for-it-9194808.html |title=State of the Future report: Humans are doing OK, but nature suffers as a result – and we’ll pay for it - Nature - Environment |publisher=The Independent |date=2014-03-16 |accessdate=2014-08-06}} 11 September 2007, Julian Borger, The Guardian, [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2007/sep/12/topstories3.mainsection Organised crime: the $2 trillion threat to the world's security], Retrieved Aug. 23, 2014, "...relentless rise of organised crime has emerged as one of the most potent threats to the planet's future, alongside global warming and the scarcity of drinkable water..." 9/10/2007, Justin Bergman, Associated Press, USA Today, [http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/nation/2007-09-10-3990070534_x.htm Reports says organized crime top problem], Retrieved Aug. 23, 2014, "...The "State of the Future" report ... said organized crime entities generated income from money laundering, counterfeiting and piracy, and the trafficking of drugs, people and arms...." JONATHAN OWEN, 16 March 2014, The Independent, [https://www.independent.co.uk/environment/nature/state-of-the-future-report-humans-are-doing-ok-but-nature-suffers-as-a-result--and-well-pay-for-it-9194808.html State of the Future report: Humans are doing OK, but nature suffers as a result – and we’ll pay for it], Retrieved Aug. 23, 2014, "...Report warns that across the world, water, essential for survival, is running low – with water tables falling in every continent..."
